>inclination would be to favor placing them in layers

To be honest I purposefully haven't put much though into visualisation 
yet since I thought it might become tricky and hopefully there are some 
papers out there that can offer some help, e.g. Ken mentioned a paper by 
Mat Buckland that offered some ideas and this would be my first port of 
call. But since we're on the subject...

Layering by distance from inputs and/or ouptuts gives us some kind of 
starting point. Only trying it and seeing the output will tell us if 
it's actually a good technique. It's easy to do it's an obvious first 
choice of visualisation to try. If it doesn;t work then we'll have to 
try something else - at least it can't be any worse than an arbitrary 
layout.

Putting a little more thought into the process we could probably get a 
better layout by placing neurons in clusters based on the number of 
interconnections. Quite how you would work that out though I have no 
idea! It sounds like one of those problems that is easy for a human to 
do but is very difficult to describe mathematicaly.

>--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
>  
>
>>[...]
>>pretty well.  The
>>one thing to make sure of is not to count a
>>recurrent connection as a
>>hop-  otherwise you can go in circles- but that
>>requires also knowing
>>which connections are recurrent, which may also be
>>difficult depending
>>how you keep track of things.  
>>

>
>Yep...good point.  We've got logic that determines
>whether a connection is recurrent at the time we
>generate the XML, so we add a boolean "recurrent" tag
>to each connection as well.
>  
>
How do you determine if a connection is recurrent? Surely it is not 
always a clearly defined thing, e.g. where there are many 
interconnections all of  the connections could potentialy participate in 
'loops'. My first approach to this problem would be to use something 
akin to a tree traversal algorithm, incrementing a 'distance from start 
point' integer as we go and storing the distance at each neuron we 
visit. Perform a complete traversal from each input neuron, If we 
encounter a neuron that has already been visited then check it's 
distance value - if it is <=currentDistance then don't traverse any 
further, if it is >currentDistance then rest it's value and traverse on 
from that point. Does that make sense? I'm not 100% sure if thise would 
work effectively or whether it would be faster/slower than the technique 
you guys are already using.

>>The problem is that
>>this method is very
>>computationally expensive, and also requires always
>>

Yeh but it's not part of the main evolution routine so we can afford cpu 
expensive code in this area- so long as it's not going to take a 
/really/ long time.

>>knowing which
>>connections are recurrent.  Once you get thousands
>>of nodes I find it
>>starts lagging out a lot before drawing anything.
>>

>
>Well, our XSL style sheet is going to be able to parse
>a network of thousands of nodes (and therefore
>probably tens or hundreds of thousands of
>connections), but I'm not sure any such graphical
>representation is going to be very human-readable, no
>matter how it's laid out, at least if it draws every
>single structure.
>  
>
Agreed. Large networks are going to be inherently hard to visualise no 
matter how you lay them out. Would still be nice to see them on screen 
and perhaps zoom in and out, etc. Perhaps we could also develop a tool 
that allows manipulation of networks, adding/removing or 
neurons/connections, that sort of thing. Ahhh, so perhaps another 
usefull XML attribute would by neuron X,Y coordinates!

Colin
